text.value: OboEditor is a quick, intuitive editor to help you make gorgeous Obojobo Modules. This tutorial will teach you how to leverage all of the capabilities provided by OboEditor to rapidly build your own custom Obojobo Modules.
The navigation panel along the left side allows for manipulation of pages and assessments. Pages are identified by the ◯ symbol, and assessments are identified by the Ⓠ symbol.

Clicking on a page or assessment name navigates to that item and loads its content into the editor. Any altered content on the current page is temporarily saved and can be viewed again by clicking back to that page. If the OboEditor is reloaded without clicking the Save Document button, the temporary changes will be deleted.
The arrow next to each page or assessment provides a menu with special actions that can be taken on each item.
Move Up swaps a page with the previous page in the list, and Move Down swaps a page with the next page in the list.
Edit Name allows you to change the name of the page.
Warning: Pages that have the same name will cause issues in the Obojobo viewer.
Delete deletes the entire page, including all of its content.
The last item in the menu is the unique id for the page. Clicking on the id copies it to the clipboard, so you can paste it elsewhere in the Editor. (see Action Buttons for some uses of ids)
The buttons at the bottom of the navigation panel provide actions that edit the entire module.
The Add Page button adds a new page to the bottom of the list of pages. The Add Assessment button adds a new assessment at the end of the assessments list.
The Rename Module button allows you to rename the entire module and will change the title at the top of the navigation panel.
The Copy Module URL button copies a URL to the clipboard. This URL allows the student to access the Obojobo module.
The Save Document button saves all temporary changes, including any changes on the current page, to the Obojobo database.
The most basic component of the OboEditor is the text node. Text nodes allow you to insert the main content of your Modules in paragraph form.
An empty text node displays a prompt for you to enter some text so that you don't lose track of where you can type.
Each text node consists of a series of one or more text lines.
Hitting the Enter key within a text node will make a new text line, which will sit just below the previous line.
Try it! Hit the Enter key after this text to make a new line.
Hitting the Enter key twice or hitting the Enter key on an empty line will create a new text node. A new text node is like a new paragraph and is separated from the previous text node accordingly.
Try it! Hit the Enter key twice after this line to make a new text node.
Text lines can also be indented. An indention applies only to a single text line, but the line will maintain the indent even when the text wraps around, as seen here.
Text Lines can also contain multiple indents, up to a maximum of 20 levels of indentation
Indents can be applied by pressing Alt+Tab, and they can be removed by pressing Shift+Tab. You can also use the indent and unindent buttons in the toolbar.
Try it! Use the Alt+Tab and Shift+Tab keys, or the toolbar buttons, to change the indent level in this line of text.
Text lines can contain whitespace such as Tabs anywhere within the line, including the beginning and the end.
Adding a Tab at the beginning of a line does not effect the indentation even if the line wraps around.
Text can also be styled. To apply styles, highlight some text and use the toolbar at the top of the page or the shortcut keys.
In addition to text nodes, you can also insert Heading nodes. These can be used to separate sections or to designate quick links.
Headings can have one of 6 different levels. To toggle the heading level, click on the arrow next to the heading and select the new heading style.

Level one headings are usually used only once on a page, as the title of the whole page. If they are not the first node on the page, they will show up as links in the navigation bar when a student views an Obojobo module.
Level two headings usually denote the major subsections of a page. They also show up as links in the navigation bar when a student views an Obojobo module.
Level three, four, five, and six headings usually denote subcategories within each subsection. These do not show up as links in the navigation bar.
Headings can also contain any of the styles that can be applied to text nodes.
Lists nodes allow for concise organization of data, in either numbered (ordered) or bullet-point (unordered) format.
You can swap between ordered and unordered lists by pressing the swap button below the list.

Lists can contain any number of levels. The level can be increased by pressing Tab or decreased by pressing Shift+Tab. You can also use the indent and unindent buttons in the toolbar to change the level.
Try it! Use Tab and Shift+Tab, or the toolbar buttons, to increase and decrease the levels of this list.
Ordered Lists have 5 distinct level markers, which they apply in this order:
If an ordered list has more than 5 levels, it will repeat markers for lower levels.
Unordered Lists only have 3 distinct level markers, applied in this order:
Just like an ordered list, if an unordered list has more than 3 levels, it will repeat markers for the lower levels.
Similar to Text nodes and Heading nodes, List nodes can contain any of the basic text styles, although they cannot be centered or right-aligned.
A Table node allows for a concise display of complex data sets. Tables can have an unlimited number of rows and columns, although a large number of columns may become unwieldy.
When a table is inserted, it only has a single cell. To add more rows and columns, use the Add Row and Add Column buttons.
Try it! Use the buttons to add a few rows and columns to this table.

Once a table has a few rows and columns, you can use the X buttons on the right side to delete rows, and the X buttons on the bottom to delete columns. Each X deletes the row or column that it is directly next to.
Deleting the last row in the table will delete the entire table.
Try it! Use the buttons to delete a few rows and columns from this table.
The header row for a table can also be toggled on or off. Use the Toggle Header button to turn the header on and off.
Accessibility Warning! Tables without headers can be very hard for text-to-speech devices to decipher. Try to use headers whenever possible.
For more information on table accessibility, read the WebAIM article about table accessibility. (Right-click to follow link)

To insert another node after a table, place your cursor at the very end of the last cell before clicking the Insert Node button. Attempting to insert a node anywhere else within the table will not succeed.
Just like List nodes, Table nodes can contain any of the basic text styles.
A Break node provides a logical and visual division on the page.
Break nodes can have one of two different widths: normal and large. To toggle in-between the two widths, click on the break and then use the Toggle Size button to alter the size.
Try it! Toggle the size of this Break.
Figure nodes allow you to display images within the Obojobo Module.
When a Figure is inserted, it has no display image. To add or change an image, click the Edit URL button and paste in the URL of the image.
Try it! Add an image to this figure.
Figures can also be displayed in several different sizes. The defaults are small, medium, and large. The size can be changed with the dropdown menu above the image.
The same image, in a medium size
The same image, in a large size

Figures can also have a custom size. The best practice for custom image sizes is to assign either a custom width or a custom height, but not both. A Figure with both a custom width and a custom height will be squished or stretched to fit.
To give a Figure a custom size, select custom from the dropdown above the image and then enter the custom values for width and/or height in the pop-up box.
Try it! Use the drop-down menu to change the size of this figure.
An image with a custom height and width
Every Figure has a caption that sits below the image. This caption will be visible to all users and can contain any of the basic text styles, just like List, Table, and Code nodes.
This caption contains text that is bold, italic, strikethrough, quoted, monospaced, latex, linked, superscript, and subscript.

Each figure also has an Alt Text attribute. The alt text will not be seen by most users, but it is displayed when the image does not load or when assistive technology such as text-to-speech devices are used. Therefore, even though it is not required, adding alt text makes your Obojobo module more accessible. To add alt text, click the Edit Alt Text button and then type the image description into the pop-up box.
Try it! Add some alt text to this image.
Add alt text to this image
Once an image has alt text, the accessibility warning above the image will disappear. The alt text can then be viewed by hovering the mouse over the image, or by clicking the Edit Alt Text button.

content.alt: A descriptive alt text for the image

text.value: This image already has alt text!
For more information on writing alt text, read the WebAIM article about alt text and accessibility. (Right-click on the link to open it)
Math Equations allow for the display of complex math equation on their own line.
To display a math equation, type the LaTeX representation of the equation into the Latex Equation box. The Math Equation will change as you type, including a notification of any errors.
Try it! Type some LaTeX into this Math Equation.
A Math Equation can also have a label. To change the label, type into the Equation Label.
Math Equations can be left aligned, centered, or right-aligned. The alignment can be changed by using the keyboard shortcuts or the toolbar.
For more information on LaTeX equations, here are a couple of helpful LaTeX tutorials. (Right-click on the links to follow them)
The Action Button node executes a series of predefined actions when clicked.  This is useful for guiding student navigation.

By default, an Action Button appears in its collapsed state, with only the label visible. This label can be edited by clicking on the Action Button and then clicking on the label a second time before typing. An Action Button without a label will cause errors in the Obojobo viewer.
Try It! Change the label on this button.
Clicking on a button also displays its list of actions, and an input field to add a new action. Clicking on a different node will collapse the button.

content.label: An Action Button with Two Actions

text.value: To add an action to an Action Button, select the action name from the dropdown menu and fill out any value that is needed for that action (see Action Details) before clicking the Save button. The OboEditor will validate the value, and then save the action into the Action Button if the value was valid. If the value was not valid, it will display an error message.
To remove an action from an Action Button, click the X button in the upper righthand corner of the action. This will delete both the action and its associated value.

Try it! Add and remove a few actions from the button below (nav:prev, nav:next, nav:lock, nav:unlock, nav:open, nav:close, and nav:toggle are the easiest ones to try since they do not require a value)
The Action Button supports a wide array of actions, some of which require an additional value in order to function properly. Here is a list of all actions that are currently supported:
The value should be a JSON object with an id property. The id property should contain the id of the page that the action is navigating to.
Opens a link to a webpage outside of the Obojobo module
The value should be a JSON object with a URL property. The URL property should contain the URL of the external webpage that the button will open. This URL must contain the http:// or https:// prefix.
Locks the navigation panel so that it cannot be used. This lock can only be removed by a nav:unlock event.
Unlocks the navigation panel so that it can be used again. If this action is executed when the panel is already unlocked, it will have no effect.
Opens the navigation panel so that the pages are all listed. If this action is executed when the panel is already open, it will have no effect.
Opens the navigation panel so that the pages are all listed. If this action is executed when the panel is already open, it will have no effect.
Toggles the navigation panel open and closed. If this action is executed when the panel is open then the panel will be closed, and vice versa.
Starts an assessment attempt for a specific assessment.
The value should be a JSON object containing an id property. The id property should contain the id of the assessment that the action is launching.
Ends an assessment attempt for a specific assessment.
The value should be a JSON object containing an id property. The id property should contain the id of the assessment that the action is terminating.
Displays an alert pop-up to the viewer.

The value should be a JSON object containing a title property and a message property. The title property should contain text that will be displayed in bold, and the message property should contain text that will be displayed at the regular size.
Example: {"title": "I have a message for you:","message": "Thanks for clicking the button"}
A Code node displays code fragments in a recognizable format.

Code nodes function similarly to text nodes.  A single Code node can contain multiple lines, including empty lines.  Code nodes can contain as many empty lines as needed.  Unlike Text nodes, two consecutive blank lines within a single Code node will not be turned into a new Code node.
Like List nodes and Text nodes, Code nodes can contain any of the basic text styles.
Monospaced Code (Not noticeably different from regular code)
YouTube nodes allow you to display YouTube videos inside of your Obojobo Module.
To change the source of the video, find the YouTube id of the video that you wish to embed, and then paste it into the id box under a YouTube node.
On YouTube, the id is the string of letters and numbers after the = in the URL. For example, a URL of https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gJ390e5sjHk would correspond to a video id of gJ390e5sjHk.

It can also be found by clicking the share button underneath the video on YouTube and then copying the string of letters and numbers at the end of the shared URL. Therefore a shared URL of https://youtu.be/gJ390e5sjHk would correspond to a video id of gJ390e5sjHk.

Questions allow you to gauge the student's comprehension of your material. Questions can be placed directly into a page as practice for the student, or they can be added to a Question Bank in the assessment.

Questions can have one of two response types: pick-one or pick-all. Pick-one questions allow the student to pick a single choice as their answer. If there is more than one correct choice, the student can select any of the correct choices to get the points for that question. Pick-all questions allow a student to select as many answers as they want. A student must select all the correct choices to get the points for that question.
Questions can also be shuffled or unshuffled. Shuffled questions will randomize the order of their choices, and unshuffled questions will retain the order of their choices.
A question contains three basic parts: the content, the multiple choice, and the solution.
The content appears at the start of the question and usually describes the question that the student is answering. It can contain any node except for Questions and Question Banks.
This Question contains both a Heading node and a Text node in its content.
How much wood could a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could chuck wood?

The multiple choice section allows you to create multiple answers for a student, and select which one(s) are correct. Just like the content, a multiple choice answer can hold any node type except for Questions and Question Banks.
Here is a question with a variety of nodes in its multiple choice section
This answer contains a Math Equation
By default, each question only has one answer. To add more, click the Add Choice button below the current choices. To delete a choice, click the X button in the upper right-hand corner of the choice.
Try it! Add and delete a few choices in this Question. (Make sure you click the X inside of a choice; the X above the question will delete the whole question)

To toggle which choices are correct, simply click on the red X or green checkmark on the left side of the choice. Choices which are marked with the green checkmark are the correct choices, and choices that are marked with the red X are incorrect. A question can have as many correct choices as you would like.

Choices can also have feedback, which provides more information to the student if they select that choice. The feedback will not be displayed to the student until they hit submit (or during a review if the question is in the assessment), so it is a good place to let them know where they went wrong, or to provide elaboration on a correct answer.
To add feedback to a choice, click the Add Feedback button. To remove feedback from a choice, simply click the X button in the upper right-hand corner of the feedback.
The feedback can contain any of the same nodes as the content and the choices.
Some more elaboration upon the answer
An answer choice without any feedback
Some details about why the answer was incorrect

The solution will display after the question has been answered. In practice questions, it is accessible after every time that the student hits submit. In the assessment, it is accessible during a full review. It will be displayed regardless of which choices the student selected, so it is a good place to put general post-question information.

To add a solution to the question, click the Add Solution button at the bottom of the question. To delete a solution, click the X button in the top right corner of the solution. The solution can contain any other node, and it can be as long as desired.
If a question has both a solution and choices with feedback, both will be displayed simultaneously.
A question with an elaborate solution
More elaboration on the incorrect answer

Question Banks allow a set of questions to be displayed together. Mostly, Question Banks are used within Assessments to select and display a certain subset of questions. Within Pages, Question Banks simply display all of their questions one after another.

Question Banks can contain both questions and other Question Banks. To add a Question or a Question Bank, click the Add Question or Add Question Bank button at the bottom of the Question Bank. To delete a Question or a Question Bank, click the X in the top right corner of the item you wish to delete.

Inside of an Assessment, a Question Bank selects a few of its children to display. The Choose property at the top of the Question Bank determines how many items are chosen. If the Choose number is greater than the number of items within the Question Bank, all of the items will be displayed.
A Question Bank also has a Select property, which determines how it picks which children to display.

Question Banks with sequential selection will pick items in order. Once an item has been used in an attempt, it will be moved to the end of the list of items to select, so that students see new or less frequently asked questions each time.
This question would be selected the first time
This question would be selected the second time
Question Banks with random selection will shuffle all items before picking them. Items can appear in any order, and may or may not be the same across attempts.
This question might be selected the first or the second time, both times, or neither time.
This other question might be selected the first or second time, both times, or neither time.

Question banks with random-unseen selection will shuffle all items and then pick randomly from the ones that have been seen less. On the student's first attempt, this is identical to random selection, but successive attempts will be guaranteed to display unseen questions if they exist.
This question might or might not be selected the first time, and will be selected the second time if it is not selected the first.
This other question might or might not be selected the first time, and will be selected the second time if it is not selected the first.
An assessment works a little differently from a regular page.
The assessment consists of four required nodes (Assessment Settings, Launch Page, Question Bank, and Score Actions) and a single optional node (Rubric).

The first required node is the assessment settings, which holds the basic parameters for the assessment. This is displayed in a box at the top of the page, and it lists the number of attempts and the review type.

The number of attempts controls how many times the student can take this assessment. Enter a number to limit the number of attempts, or type unlimited to allow the student to try as many times as they want.
The review type describes how answers will be displayed after an attempt has ended.
A value of never means that the student will only see whether or not they got a question wrong after every attempt. Correct answers will not be shown.
A value of always means that the student will see both incorrect responses and the correct answers after every attempt.
A value of no-attempts-remaining means that the student will see whether or not they got a question wrong after every attempt. Correct answers are shown after the final attempt.
The second required node is the launch page. This is the page that a student sees the first time they navigate to an assessment.

Somewhere on the launch page, there should be an Action Button that executes the assessment:attemptStart action. When clicked, this button will allow the student to start the assessment. Here is an example of the launch button:
The third required node is the Question Bank. This Question Bank functions the same way as a Question Bank within a page.

The fourth required node is the list of Score Actions. Score Actions are the pages that are displayed at the top of a review after a student has completed an attempt. Different Score Actions can be displayed for different score ranges.

To describe a score range, use square brackets to denote an inclusive range, so that [0,100] would match all scores from 0 to 100, including 0 and 100. Use parenthesis to denote an exclusive range, such that (0, 100) would match all scores between 0 and 100, and would not match 0 or 100. Square brackets and parenthesis can also be mixed and matched, allowing for ranges such as [0,100), which matches all scores except 100, and (0,100], which matches all scores except 0. Any two numbers can be placed between the brackets and parenthesis, and the numbers should be separated by a comma.
In most cases, Score Actions should contain an Action Button that executes the assessment:attemptStart action, just like the Launch Page. This will allow the students to complete multiple attempts.
The fifth node in the assessment is an optional Rubric. The Rubric allows you to set custom parameters about passing and failing scores for the assessment.
When processing the student's score, the assessment first determines their raw score by dividing the number of questions correct by the total number of questions and then multiplying by 100.

Then the Rubric checks the raw score, and if it is greater than or equal to the Passing Score, then the rubric declares that the student passed. If the student passed, the Passed Result is sent to the grade book. If the raw score is less than the Passing Score, then the Failed Result is sent to the grade book. If the student takes all of their allowed attempts and does not achieve at least one Passing Score, then the Unable to Pass Result will be sent to the grade book.

The Rubric also allows you to set up to 20 mods that change the student's score. These are bonus points that are added to a Passed Result after the student achieves a Passing Score. The Attempt Condition describes which attempts could receive the mod, either as a range of values (written similarly to the range of scores in Score Actions), a single value, or as the variable $last_attempt. The reward describes how many points to add to the Passed Result, with positive numbers increasing the score (up to a maximum of 100) and negative number decreasing the score.

In this assessment, the Rubric lists a 75% as the Passing Score and sets the Passed Result and Failed Result so that students who make at least 75% will receive a 100%, but students who do not make at least 75% will receive a 0%. Students who take all three attempts and never make at least a 75% will receive a score of 50%. There are also mods that show all of the possible options for ranges and rewards.
